talk.start.para: âWith regard to the 27 bills before usâand I am sure there are many more to comeâthe government has two main and separate objectives, and they are separate objectives. The first is to get its tax package through, but the second main objective is to diminish and attack the Senate. The government intends to do that by attacking its process, its members and the Senate committees and their reports.

speech.para: Out there in the scheming world where these sorts of plots are hatched, we know that a fewânot many, but a fewâbullyboys in business, the usual suspects, are building up their war chest for an assault on the Senate as well, and they will add a great deal of money to the campaign to try to propagandise against the Senate. Yet the Senate, as a proportional representation body, truly does represent the people of Australia. As Senator Forshaw made clear in his remarks, only 37 per cent of the vote in the Senate went to the coalition in the last electionâtheir worst result in the last 60 years. I would not just venture to suggest, I would state as a fact, that that low percentage was entirely a result of the GST and the ANTS tax package.

Because of that, this package must be rejected by the Senate unless fiercely amended because, without its acceptance by sufficient senators other than the coalition, it will lack the legitimacy of popular support which any major change should enjoy. If the last election, which the Prime Minister insists had as its centrepieceâand I think he is rightâthe GST and the new tax system package, had been a referendum or even just a plebiscite, the government would have failed to get a majority of Australians to support it. You can twist and turn about who has mandates, which mandates they are and where the mandates exist, but you cannot get away from the fact that a majority of Australians did not vote for the coalition's tax package as they put it. Therefore, the Senate must either reject it or savagely amend it to make it more acceptable to the community as a whole.

I think the community as a whole need to be very alert to the way in which a number of people within the political process are seeking to use this process to reduce the power, the impact and the personality of the Senate. This is the same agenda which seeks to advance the power of the Prime Minister in the presidential republican debate. This is the same agenda which reduces the tenure of the clerks of both houses. This is the same agenda which reduces the independence of the senior bureaucrats who run our civil service. This is the same agenda that seeks to appoint capital `C' conservative judges to the High Court. It is a desire for excessive executive power. In the exercise of its role in legislation, this Senate must resist the efforts of a number of senators, particularly in the Liberal Party, to demean and diminish the Senate, the senators and its process.

With those remarks I want to draw attention to some of the remarks made by Senator Ferguson yesterday. I have known Senator Ferguson since I came into the Senate, and I have found him to be an exceptionally capable, cooperative and very accommodating senator on the Senate economics committees and other committees where I have interacted with him. But from the moment he entered the Senate Select Committee on A New Tax System he seemed to undergo a personality change, and I think he exhibited far more aggression than is normal for the man as I know him. Either that is the strain of the responsibility of defending an indefensible package or, alternatively, he was under orders to be far more disruptive than is his nature.

When he made remarks about the behaviour of senators in the Labor Party I was distressed, not because some of those remarks might not be trueâbecause there are senators who go over the top, as we might sayâbut because it was a one-eyed approach. We all know that within his own coalition there are senators who go over the top. Any remarks about the fierce nature of politics and the way in which people conduct themselves in committees have to be remarks about behaviour as a whole and not directed at one particular political party. But there was one thing he said with which I do want to agree. There were remarks made yesterday by Senator Conroy implying bias by the Senate committee secretariat. I will say clearly that I have worked with Robert Diamond on the IR report and numerous other reports since mid-1996, and he is not a person who exhibits bias in the conduct of his duties. Madam President, I think I have got to stop here.

That the provisions of paragraphs (5) to (7) of standing order 111 not apply to the Further 1998 Budget Measures Legislation Amendment (Social Security) Bill 1999, allowing it to be considered during this period of sittings.

Leave granted.
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1999 WINTER SITTINGS MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (TEMPORARY SAFE HAVEN VISAS) BILL 1999
The proposed Bill will make amendments to the Migration Act 1958 in relation to temporary safe haven visas. The amendments will:
. provide the legislative framework for the Australian Government to provide persons with temporary safe haven in Australia;
. ensure that persons to whom temporary safe haven is provided are unable to change their status to remain in Australia after temporary safe haven is no longer necessary; and

. provide temporary safe haven for 4,000 persons displaced from their homes in Kosovo, consistent with the Government's commitment on 6 April 1999. Any applications made from that date will be rendered invalid.

The Bill also contains specific powers to enable prompt action to be taken to withdraw temporary safe haven to persons who represent a danger to the Australian community, or Australia's security or whose presence in Australia would be harmful to Australia's international relations.

Introduction and passage in the same Sittings is required to enable the Government to implement the short term humanitarian measures required for Australia to accept 4,000 displaced Kosovar Albanians.

para.inline: Effect if Bill is not dealt with in one Sittings

speech.para: Delay in implementation will frustrate Australia's efforts to assist in alleviating suffering and human tragedy in Kosovo.
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1999 AUTUMN SITTINGS
FURTHER 1998 BUDGET MEASURES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (SOCIAL SECURITY) BILL 1999

The Further 1998 Budget Measures Legislation Amendment (Social Security) Bill 1999 will deal with a number of 1998 Budget measures and some non-Budget measures relating to international social security agreements.

The commencement dates for the measures vary. However, there are some measures that are scheduled to commence on 1 July 1999. In order to meet the implementation time frames, including final development of supporting systems and administration, it will be necessary to have the amending legislation in place before the end of the 1999 Autumn Sittings.

talk.start.para: âDuring the summer break, I chose to go the island of Borneo to look at the war graves in those areas that have, for over 50 years, been synonymous with the most brave of actions of young Australian warriors during the Pacific war, the 1939-45 war. I travelled to what is called Kota Kinabalu, which was, during those years that young Australians served on that island, named Jesselton. The area is today called Sabah, but during the time of the British Empire, of which Australia was a part, it was called British North Borneo.

speech.para: I drove some 300 kilometres through the mountains of Borneo to Sandakan and went to the camp from which over 1,000 young Australians marched, on two separate occasions, high into the mountains of Borneoâin January 1945 and again in May 1945. In the first march, 455 young Australians, mostly in their twenties, were force marched by the Japanese to Ranau, which lies adjacent to Mount Kinabalu, the highest mountain peak in Borneo. Later, 530 young Australians were force marched. Altogether, of about 2,700 young Australians who were imprisoned in the Sandakan prison camp, only six young Australians survived. That is in itself a tragedy when any of them, with even a modicum of humane treatment, could have returned to their mothers, their fathers, their families and their loved ones.

In five days time, Australia will be asked to remember those sacrifices that young men and some young women made; we call it Anzac Day. It is, in my mind, without exception the greatest day in Australia's history. There is no day that comes closer to exemplifying this hard-won island nation than Anzac Day, to be held in five days time. I was fortunate enough to be much too young to serve in the Second World War and thenâby, I guess, some grace of Godâtoo old to serve in the Vietnam War, but I was called up for national service. I served in the Australian Army somewhat grudgingly at the time, but in retrospect it was a privilege to serve my country as a national serviceman.

It was not until I left national service in the fifties that I realised how much Australians of the age that I was had given in order that I could enjoy one of the best and most enviable lives that anyone in the world could possibly have. And to those young men and young women who gave their lives in all our wars and conflicts so that I could enjoy freedom, I say, with as much truth as I can muster: thank you so much. On behalf of all Australians who hold history and our country dear, may I presume to say to those people who sacrificed their lives: thank you also.

I was privileged to read a document that was put out by this government 54 years after the Second World War. There are many poignant parts to it. Having been to Sandakan and having inspected the camp from which these young Australians were forcibly marched to be shot or to die in the jungle or to be otherwise executed, it brought back memories today of that rather sparse camp on the edges of the jungle of Borneo in which stands in mute testimony to those who served so well and sacrificed so much, a steam shovel that is still left there that was damaged by the Australians who were asked by the Japanese to build a war stripâthey damaged the shovel to the degree that it could not be usedâand a rather archaic generator, the shell of which still remains, that lit the camp, no doubt not for the Australians who were imprisoned there but for the Japanese and for the officers mess. These are rather tragic reminders of an age 50 or 60 years ago. When I look around and see the affluence and the comfort we live in today, I feel rather ashamed of myself. I want to read from the book, called Laden, fevered, starved: the POWs of Sandakan North Borneo, 1945. On page 47 it states:
The 183 survivors of the second marchâ
that is, the march in Mayâ
142 Australians and 41 Britishâbegan arriving at Ranauâ
that is, the place in the mountains of Borneoâ
on 26 June 1945. They found only six men from the first marchâ
that is, of the 455 who leftâ

still alive. Over the next few weeks, despite their exhaustion, sickness and malnutrition, they were subjected to a harsh and brutal work regime. Parties cut bamboo, collected wood for burning, atap for hut construction, and carried 20-kilogram bags of food to Ranau from a dump three kilometres away. This was light work compared to that of those unfortunates who were assigned to haul an average of 130 buckets of water a day up a steep slope for the Japanese officers' quarters. As private Keith Botterill later testified, rations for the POWs at this time were barely sufficient for survival, let alone for sick men . . .
Keith Botterill said:

para.inline: They were given a small cup of rice water a day with about an inch of rice in the bottom. Plenty of rice was available and the Japanese used to get a 800 grams a day themselves; they also used to get tapioca, meat, eggs and sweet potatoes and showed no signs of malnutrition.

speech.para: The book continues:

No accommodation was available for those from the second group and initially they were herded together in an area 50 metres square. There was no place for cooking or basic sanitation, and living quarters were simply the protection of the scrub. Between 30 June and 18 July, as well as working for the Japanese, the POWs built themselves a hut. A measure of their physical condition by this time was the fact that when the hut was finished only 38 were fit enough to occupy its elevated floor space. The remainder were so sick and debilitated by dysentery and other illness that they could only crawl under the hut for shelter.

Keith Botterill estimated that in early July men died at the rate of about 7 every day. Moreover, the beatings and the bashings continued. One POW who perished as a result of a severe bashing was Sapper `Dickie' Bird, a survivor of the first death march. By 7 July Bird was emaciated with beriberi, malaria and leg ulcers but, despite his condition, a Japanese guard dragged him out for work. When he tried to explain his incapacity Bird was knocked to the ground and continually kicked for over ten minutes. Later that evening he was observed lying virtually where he had fallen and an effort was made to get him back to the hut. Bird was in great agony and he lapsed into a coma. Nothing could be done for him and he died two days later. An Australian doctor, Captain J B Oakeshott, was so appalled by the manner of Sapper Bird's death that he purportedly declared:

para.inline: If anybody is fortunate enough to escape this camp or live it out, this incident with others should be brought to the notice of the authorities and see that justice is brought about.

speech.para: We do owe a lot. It is a sacred day for Australians. To all of those 61,000 young men who died and did not come home from Europe in that event of 1914, to those 45,000 who perished in the Second World War, to those who perised in all of our wars, may I conclude by saying: I hope you rest well. Lest we forget.

talk.start.para: âThis evening I want to draw attention to the fact that 30 April is the deadline for comment on the Constitutional Alteration (Preamble) Bill 1999 exposure draft. There has, of course, been extensive debate about the preamble that has been presented by the Prime Minister. Many people have penned their own preambles. It has created a great deal of debate, which is a good thing. It has created some controversy, which is, I believe, also a good thing, because it gets people thinking about the issues of what it means to be Australian and why we in Australia want to change the way in which we are governed in terms of recognition of an Australian head of state.

speech.para: I do not want to spent a lot of time on the controversial aspects because, obviously, there are a number of features of the Prime Minister's draft that I cannot agree with. But my three major criticisms are as follows. The first is that I think it is too wordy. With every respect to Les Murray, there are too many words. This is the kind of statement that people should be able to remember, and in the current form it is far too difficult for people to remember the actual flow of the sentences. In fact, unfortunately, they do not flow. The two more substantive issues relate to its failure to recognise indigenous prior occupation and custodianship of the land. Many, many people have commented that this is non-negotiable, and I believe that the Prime Minister would be well advised to think again about recognising prior occupation and, particularly, custodianship.

There is another key area that I believe is really a grave oversight on the part of the Prime Ministerâand Les Murray has to accept some of the responsibility. That is that the preamble, as presently drafted, fails to recognise 52 per cent of the population. It does not mention women. Now there will be those who say, `Why should it?' I believe that, for a number of reasons, I can persuade you that it should. For example, there is Jocelyn Newman's comment on Monday in a letter to the editor of the Australian. Under the banner headline `A fair go for women,' she wrote:
I welcome healthy debate about women's policy and the need to give voice to a wide diversity of experience and aspirations.
Well, how can you have a preamble if it does not give voice to the wide diversity of experience and aspirations of 52 per cent of the population?

Furthermore, it should be remembered that on two occasions that I know of the Prime Minister, to his credit, did commit himself to the inclusion in the preamble of equality of men and women before the law. The first occasion was on 14 February on the Ten network's Meet the Press in answer to a question from Michelle Grattan. He did it again on 16 February at a coalition party room meetingâagain, reported in the Australian and the Canberra Times on 17 February. Obviously, it has been in the Prime Minister's mind to recognise the equality of women and men in the preamble, but apparently it has either slipped his mindâI will be generousâor he has failed to keep that promise. Not only did he fail to keep that promise, he gave us `mateship' instead. That word is very blokey and in no way acceptable to many women and, indeed, men as being a substitute for recognising equality between men and women.
I will quote Marian Sawer, who has done a great deal of work on this subject and on the Constitutional Convention, as have a number of other women:
It is difficult to discover why the Preamble Working Party at the Constitutional Convention regarded the equality of men and women as `controversial' . . .

Here we are in 1999 and certain peopleâbe it the Prime Minister or Malcolm Turnbullâstill seem to think that to recognise the facts of life is somehow controversial. This principle has been included in all recent government statements of the core values of Australians. For example, changes to the Australian Citizenship Act were introduced in this way:

Australia is a parliamentary democracy committed to providing equality before the law, freedom of the individual, freedom of speech and religion, equality between men and women and equality of opportunity for all.

This is in the Senate Hansard of 6 May 1993. So any comment that it is too controversial and perhaps best left alone is really very out of step with the reality of the roles of men and women in Australian society today.

I am told by Marian Sawer, who has researched this area extensively, that all democracies which have revised their constitutions since World War II have formally recognised that men and women are equal. Australia's former trust territory, Papua New Guinea, has recognised men and women in its preamble. Finland has addressed equal pay in its constitution, which says:
Equality of the sexes shall be promoted in social activities and in working life, particularly in the determination of remuneration.
Malta's constitution says:
The State shall promote the equal right of men and women to enjoy all economic, social, cultural, civil and political rights.
And, of course, the recognition of the equality of men and women is already an obligation on Australia under the Convention on Civil and Political Rights.

I would very much hope that women and forward-looking menâand I am sure both of the senators sitting on the government benches at the moment are such gentlemenâwill be able in the party room to persuade the Prime Minister that he has to take out of the preamble this football field nonsense about being all good mates together and include a statement that reflects the reality in Australia and the commitment that we should have to our obligation under the relevant convention.

In conclusion, I have to confess that I have not drafted a preamble for consideration by the Prime Minister. I am sure that he would accept one from me, but I do not know how successful I would be in persuading him. Instead, I would like to conclude by reading Marian Sawer's preamble because I think it does overcome many of the issues that I have raised tonight. It is simple. It is easy to remember. It includes recognition of indigenous custodianship of the land. It states:

We the people of Australia affirm our Constitution as the foundation of our democracy. We dedicate ourselves to a responsible and representative system of government that upholds fundamental rights and freedoms and the rule of law.

We respect and cherish our ancient land and recognise indigenous Australians as its original occupants and custodians. We seek an Australia that is proud of its diversity, promotes the equality of men and women and provides justice and equity for all.
I commend the sentiments of that preamble to the Senate and indeed to the Prime Minister when he is considering the final draft of the preamble.

(3) Has the Minister inquired as to whether Mr Beaver's action would have been in breach of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act; if not, will such an inquiry be undertaken.
(5) Did Mr Beaver: (a) attempt to access Airservices staff members e-mail accounts in the course of his inquiry; and (b) seek authority to access these accounts; if so, was authority granted.
(6) Who gave Mr Beaver authority to access these accounts.
(7) Can a copy of Mr Beaver's report be provided; if not, why not.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Airservices Australia has advised that:
(1) Yes.
(2) The tapes accessed by Mr Beaver are recorded for operational security reasons and are not covered by any Airservices/Union agreement.
(3) Airservices Australia is satisfied that Mr Beaver's action did not breach the Telecommunications (Interception) Act.
(5) (a) Yes

subdebateinfo.title: Air Traffic Control Computer Systems: Millennium Bug
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 191)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Has Airservices Australia concluded all audits of air traffic control radar and flight information computer systems with regard to the `millennium bug'.

(3) Is the IRDS year 2000 (millennium bug) compliant.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Airservices Australia has advised that:

(1) Airservices has a comprehensive program covering all aspects of its business. At this time, the majority of Airservices' internal systems have had the Year 2000 issue addressed. In some cases, the remedied or replacement systems are being placed into production during the first half of 1999. Testing and renovation of some existing systems is continuing in 1999. Some suppliers have undertaken to provide software upgrades in early 1999, or are yet to advise on the status of their embedded componentry. talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 1 December 1998:

question.para: With reference to the past practice in which the Prime Minister has supplied answers across portfolios relating to the employment of departmental liaison officers (DLOs):
(1) What is the standard allocation of DLOs per portfolio minister and per non-portfolio minister and parliamentary secretary.
(2) In each instance how many DLOs have been allocated to each minister and parliamentary secretary.
(3) In each instance what are the responsibilities of each DLO, where allocated on account of a major agency etc.
(4) Which ministers have been allocated escort officers and how many.
(5) Which ministers have staff undergoing short-term developmental experience in the offices of ministers and parliamentary secretaries, for example, Graduate Administrative Assistants, and how many.
(6) What are the number of staff from the department and Cabinet's Parliamentary Liaison Office assisting the Leader of the House and the Manager of Government Business in the Senate.

talk.start.para: âThis answer replaces the answer previously supplied to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The standard allocation is two DLOs for portfolio ministers, and one for non-portfolio ministers and parliamentary secretaries. There are exceptions to the standard allocation, usually where a minister has responsibility for more than one major agency, either within the portfolio or another portfolio, or for times of peak activity requiring additional liaison.
(2) See Table 1 (attached) for DLOs currently allocated.

(3) The DLOs have responsibility for facilitating liaison between the minister and the department or agency in relation to administrative and policy matters. The range of duties varies depending on the level and skills of the DLO, as well as on the work priorities of the minister's office and department or agency from time to time.

(4) Consistent with past practice, the Minister for Defence, the Hon John Moore, MP, and the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, the Hon Bruce Scott, MP, have each been allocated one escort officer.

(5) Consistent with past practice, public servants may undertake short-term developmental opportunities in ministers' offices. The Office of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs regularly takes a placement from the Department of Veterans' Affairs' Graduate Administrative Assistant program.

(6) The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet provides four staff in the parliamentary liaison role. One parliamentary liaison officer (PLO) and an assistant to the PLO are made available in the House of Representatives and the Senate.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 7 December 1998:

(3) Can it be confirmed that a number of replacement controllers were excluded from being called in as a consequence of the 8 day rule introduced by Mr Ludlow.
(4) Can it be confirmed that the closure was a result of Mr Ludlow's 8 day rule rather than the 10 day rule provided for in the Airservices enterprise bargaining agreement.
(5) Has Airservices Australia now withdrawn Mr Ludlow's 8 day rule; if so, when did this occur.
(6) Was Mr Ludlow's 8 day rule withdrawn following a hearing of the industrial Relations Commission.

(7) With reference to part 4 of the answer to question on notice no. 1, which states that the 10 day rule is a maximum and is subject to a `variation based on local circumstances': can a copy be provided of the document(s) that state that rostering principles are subject to `variation based on local circumstances'.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âRepresenting the Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Airservices Australia has advised that:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 1 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of advice from the Australian Government Solicitor to the Heritage Protection Section of the Department of Communications and the Arts on 6 August 1997, to the effect that Jervoise Bay lies beyond the geographical limits of the State of Western Australia and that it is part of `Australian waters'.
(2) Does the Minister agree that significant development projects in Australian waters should be subject to federal rather than state environment protection legislation.

(3)In the light of this advice from the Australian Government Solicitor, will an environmental impact assessment of the proposed development of harbour facilities in Jervoise Bay be initiated under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I understand that advice has been given that Jervoise Bay lies within "Australian waters" as defined in the Historic Shipwrecks Act 1976. I am advised that the expression as used in that Act includes waters over which the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 recognises State legislative powers.

(2) The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 (EPIP Act) applies to environmentally significant Commonwealth actions, regardless of the location of the project to which the action relates, and even though State or Territory legislation also applies to the project. The EPIP Act does not seek to exclude State and Territory environment assessment processes. In fact, the Administrative Procedures approved under section 6 of the EPIP Act oblige me, when deciding what assessment action is required, to take account of any relevant assessments by a State or Territory.

(3) I have already considered the Jervoise Bay project in accordance with the EPIP Administrative Procedures and provided a recommendation to the Commonwealth Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. I took account of the assessment of the project carried out by the Western Australia Government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 8 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Why does the Government not provide the concession/discount benefits to early independent retirees that it extends to older retirees/pensioners.

(2) Would it not be of benefit to the Government to provide some incentive for eligible workers to take early retirement as they continue to pay taxes and create new employment opportunities for younger people.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) Budget resources for social security purposes are limited and assistance is targeted to those most in need.One targeting method is means testing based on income and assets. Another method, which has been part of Australia's age pension system since its inception at the beginning of this century, is to limit assistance to those above the `age pension age', currently 65 for men and 61 for women (increasing to 65 by 2013). Extending the same concessions currently available to age pensioners, to younger people, would involve additional costs to the Budget, and ultimately to taxpayers.

The Government is also keen to ensure that people have the opportunity, during their working lives, to accumulate savings sufficient to provide them with a comfortable income in retirement. For most, this is most likely to be achieved if they do not retire early from the workforce. To assist people to accumulate retirement savings, the Government provides substantial tax concessions in support of superannuation. In addition, some recent initiatives have encouraged people to extend the number of years they remain in the workforce. In particular, the Government has introduced the Pension Bonus Scheme and now allows people who have a genuine attachment to the workforce to continue contributing to superannuation until they are 70 years old. If older people do remain longer in the workforce the Government does not believe that this will cause any significant displacement of jobs for younger people. Moreover national income and tax revenues are likely to be boosted.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 8 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Will there be any assessment by Centrelink on the success (or otherwise) of the current work ability tables (WATs) for clients with a psychiatric disability.

(2) Because mental illness is usually episodic in nature and many Centrelink clients with a psychiatric disability lack insight about their disability, thereby making the work ability information assessment unreliable, how then can they not be disadvantaged by this system.
(3) Considering the unreliability of WATs for clients with a psychiatric disability, how does the Government expect to receive accurate information from the current application of the new WATs.

(4) Why, when a national pilot of WATs was undertaken with the assistance of 90 people with a mental illness, which showed that WATs did not determine disability levels are the WATs now being used to determine disability levels.

(5) On what basis is the Minister assuming the WATs score accurately reflects the support needs of people with psychiatric disability and consequently the type of employment service they require to be streamed towards.

(6) Why, when international research shows that work capacity of people with psychiatric disability cannot be measured using assessment tools such as WATs is Australia choosing to use such a test for such a purpose.

(7) Does the Government intend to use the WATs score for any other purpose than the broad streaming of people with psychiatric disability to the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business or the Department of Family and Community Services (FaCS) funded services, for example, to determine funding levels under proposed case-based funding trials for FaCS funded services.

(8) Why, when there has been a national uproar about the use of WATs from almost every disability group and even from within Centrelink itself, is the Government considering basing $5 million of case-based funding on the score a disabled person obtains from the WATs.

(9) Why, when universities and institutes have shown that the reliability and the validity of WATs is highly questionable and it has never been validated in any form for people with psychiatric disabilities, is the Government continuing to force people to complete the test and receive services on the basis of an invalid score.
(10) As the current WATs system is not sensitive to the needs of people with a psychiatric disability, would the Minister consider a more suitable alternative assessment process.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. However, the Department of Family and Community Services (FaCS) is evaluating the effectiveness of the WATs as a streaming tool for job seekers with disabilities, including those with psychiatric disabilities.

(2) Work ability information is derived from information provided by the job seeker and from professionals nominated by the job seeker. Professionals include treating doctors, counsellors, social workers, teachers, etc. Centrelink provides training and guidelines to its staff, including its Disability Officers, to ensure that people from all disability groups are identified and assessed effectively. If a job seeker with a disability is dissatisfied with Centrelink's employment assessment decision, they can seek a review. Job seekers with disabilities can also directly approach a specialist disability employment service of their choice, who can support them through the assessment process.

(3) The WATs tool was trialled between 1995 and 1997. People with psychological/psychiatric disabilities constituted the second largest population in the study. The results for this group were consistent with the overall population. The WATs was found to be the best available determinant of work ability across a range of disability groups. There is no clear evidence at this stage to indicate that the WATs tool discriminates against any group in estimating work ability. On behalf of the Disability Industry Reference Group, FaCS has recently commissioned further research into the effectiveness of the WATs as a streaming tool for job seekers with particular disabilities.
(4) See answer to Q. (3)

(5) The WATs tool is not used to assess support needs. It is only used as a streaming tool between mainstream employment services and specialist disability employment services. Specialist disability employment services assess the support needs of each individual and develop appropriate programs.

(6) The assessment tool is only used to differentiate people best suited to mainstream employment services or specialist disability employment services. In 1996 the Department of Health and Family Services assessed 87 existing instruments worldwide and found the WATs to be the most effective assessment tool available.

(7) At this stage, the WATs tool is only being used to inform the eligibility for the Disability Support Pension (DSP) and to stream people with disabilities to employment assistance. A departmental industry working group (comprised of representatives from ACROD, the National Caucus of Disability Consumer Organisations, and the Association of Competitive Employment) is considering funding models and administrative requirements for the case-based funding trials.
(8) See answer to Q. (7).

(9) The WATs tool is the best available determinant of work ability. However, a research project is being commissioned to assist the Disability Industry Reference Group provide advice on the impact of the WATs tool on the profile of job seekers using FaCS-funded services.
(10) Yes. A number of alternatives have already been considered. Recent proposals from ACROD and the Psychiatric Inter-agency Meeting of Employment Services are currently being considered.

talk.start.para: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 8 March 1999:

question.para: Given that it is unlawful to discriminate against a person in an employment matter because of the person's lawful political activities or beliefs: Has an application been made by the Australian Electoral Commission for an exemption from this requirement for staff employed by the Commission; if so what was the outcome of the application.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: An application was made by the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) to the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission in 1993 for an exemption under the discrimination provisions (s.22B) of the Public Service Act 1922.

As a result of this application, Executive Council approved a new Public Service Regulation 71AA on 6 July 1993 which permits discrimination on the basis of political activities or beliefs in appointments, transfers and promotions, where that discrimination is essential for the effective performance of the duties of an officer in, or as an unattached officer of, the AEC.
The AEC's policy on political neutrality does not breach the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986. The Act allows discrimination based on the "inherent requirements of the job".

talk.start.para: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 8 March 1999:

question.para: What was the extent and cost of habitation reviews undertaken by the Australian Electoral Commission between March 1996 and October 1998.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: Habitation reviews or roll reviews, including inquiry at habitable addresses by field staff, review by mail (particularly in rural areas) and general checks on address details are organised and carried out by the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) at the state and territory level. The reviews undertaken for the period requested are set out below.
(a) New South Wales: A full review using both fieldwork and mail review was undertaken between February and July 1998 and the total cost was $5.5 million.

(b) Victoria: During 1997/98 targeted review activity was undertaken in country and outer Melbourne areas in connection with rural road numbering. The total cost was $95,000. From February to August 1998 a review of non-rural areas was undertaken by fieldwork and by limited mail review. The total cost was $3.5 million.

(c) Queensland: Between July 1996 and January 1997 a pilot study of a continuous roll update was undertaken in Queensland using Australia Post's change of address data backed up with limited fieldwork, at a total cost of $450,000. A full review using both fieldwork and mail review was undertaken between July 1997 and February 1998. The total cost was $3 million.

(d) South Australia: Pre review checks of vacant habitations and postal address checks were undertaken between March 96 and June 1997 at a cost of $17,000. A full review using both fieldwork and mail review was undertaken between July 1997 and October 1998. The total cost was $1.1 million.
(e)Western Australia: A full review using both fieldwork and mailing was undertaken between February and August 1998, at a total cost of $1.7 million.

(f) Tasmania: In 1996/97, $20,000 was expended on limited change of address mailings plus checks on rural addresses. Between August and October 1997 a full state review was undertaken, at a total cost of $420,000. In June 1998 review mailing to vacant addresses took place, at a total cost of $15,000.

(g) Australian Capital Territory: A partial review of high growth areas took place between February and May 1997, at a total cost of $30,000. A full review took place between August 1997 and February 1998, at a total cost of $280,000.

(h) Northern Territory: Limited review activity targeting high growth areas took place between April and June 1997, at a total cost of $65,000. A full review of the Territory took place between February and August 1998, at a total cost of $260,000. Note that while all fieldwork was completed prior to the 1998 federal election certain follow up activities were not finished by October 1998.

(i) National Review Activities: Prior to the close of rolls for the Constitutional Convention Election in 1997, national mailing took place to vacant addresses held by the AEC and to addresses at which Australia Post had received a change of address notification. Total cost of this roll review activity was approximately $1 million. So that enrolment forms can be obtained from new citizens, the AEC arranges for the pre-printing of enrolment forms with citizenship certificates and their collection at ceremonies at an annual cost of $350,000.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Electoral Commission: Provision of Electoral Services
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 484)

talk.start.para: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 8 March 1999:

question.para: (1) What instances does the Australian Electoral Commission provide electoral services to organisations on a competitive or cost recovery basis.
(2) Where it does so, what is the charging regime applied by the Commission.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) provides all non-parliamentary electoral services to organisations on a competitive or cost recovery basis in situations, except:
* where there is a statutory requirement for the AEC to conduct the elections free of charge, for example, elections conducted under the Workplace Relations Act 1996;
* where the AEC has been directed by the Federal Court to conduct a ballot, or
* where the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has directed that a secret ballot be conducted and the AEC has agreed to conduct the ballot.

(2) The AEC conducts elections and ballots for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Act 1989. Funding for this is provided by ATSIC.

For all other elections and ballots, the AEC charges on the basis of full cost recovery as a minimum. This calculation includes overheads, return on capital and project management costs. Australian Electoral Officers have the discretion to include additional amounts for risk management or other relevant factors.

answer.para: (1) The cost to the department in 1998-99 is expected to be approximately $176,000. Improvements in the efficiency of the production process have led to a reduction in the cost of production by approximately 50% over the past three years, from approximately $350,000 per annum in 1996.
